First Steps.
Securing the cooperation of the San Bernardino Sun-Telegram - an outstanding
newspaper and the only one serving the entire San Bernardino Valley - became the
first task. This was arranged in an interview with Mr. James A. Guthrie, Sun-
Tele gram publisher. This publisher, with a long record of distinguished service
to the community, listened to one of the programs and liked it. He visualized the
possibility of developing new channels of communication for bringing important
problems to the consideration of the people. As detailed later in this report, the
Sun-Telegram gave generously of "white space" both to print the discussion guides
and to carry news stories relating to the Experiment.
Radio Station KFXM was next approached as offering one of the best listening
publics in the area. The station management auditioned the program and volunteered
not only a choice and convenient listening time (8:30-9:00 p.m. Thursday) but
agreed to aid in the promotion of listenership and individual participation.
The support of one other key organization was deemed essential. This was the
Chamber of Commerce, which auditioned one of the programs at a breakfast meeting
of its Board of Directors. After listening to a presentation of the whole philos¬
ophy behind the Experiment, with particular attention to its significance as a new
communication technique, the Chamber gave enthusiastic endorsement to the Experiment
and aided considerably in its local promotion.
